title.narrative: UNOPS PARLAD 2014-2018 Open and Democratic Parliament
UNOPS PARLAD 2014-2018 Open and Democratic Parliament

description.narrative:
A consortium consisting of the four organizations CEG, LEGIS, NDI and NIMD has applied for funding from Sweden concerning "Citizen support programme for a democratic and open parliament - PARLAD" during the period 2014-2018. The intervention, which in total is on 37,5 million SEK, will be administered and coordinated by UNOPS.
The general objective of the intervention is to contribute to technical and institutional strengthening of the legislative function and the Parliament through organized citizen participation aiming at transforming the political system and developing a democratic legislative framework, by 1) promoting international standard in legislation concerning Human Rights, security, justice and transparency; 2) Articulation and consolidation of civil society networks for fiscalization, technical assistance and advocacy in relation to the Congress; 3) Establishment of mechanisms for analysis, dialogue and information based on studies and social audit mechanisms.

Ett konsortium bestående av de fyra organisationerna CEG, LEGIS, NDI och NIMD har ansökt om finansiering från Sverige gällande "Citizen support programme for a democratic and open parliament - PARLAD" under perioden 2014-2018. Insatsen som är på totalt 37,5 miljoner SEK administreras och koordineras av UNOPS.
Insatsens huvudmål att att bidra till tekniskt och institutionellt stärkande av den lagstiftande funktionen och parlamentet i Guatemala genom organiserat medborgardeltagande som syftar till en genomgripande förändring av det politiska systemet och utvecklingen av att demokratiskt ramverk för lagstiftningen. Detta kommer att ske genom att 1) främja en internationell standard i lagstiftningen gällande mänskliga rättigheter, säkerhet, rättsskipning och transparens, 2) främja och konsolidera deltagande av civilsamhällesnätverk för ansvarsutkrävande, tekniskt stöd och påverkansarbete i relation till kongressen, 3) etablera mekanismer för analys, dialog och information baserad på studier och mekanismer för ansvarsutkrävande.

description.narrative: During this reporting cycle, the political context in Guatemala for program implementation has been challenging. Tensions have escalated in Congress and in the Executive Branch as a consequence of the fight against corruption and impunity. President Jimmy Morales publicly attacked CICIG and Commissioner Ivan Velasquez declaring him Non-grato, and relations with Public Prosecutor's Office deteriorated during Thelma Aldana's period. President Morales's government requested Sweden to change their Ambassador to Guatemala, probably due to Sweden's strong financial support to CICIG. Congress on the other hand has been strongly criticized for inefficiency and protection of their own interests against possible corruption charges. The current Board of Directors of the Congress has closed it's doors to international cooperation in an attitud of defiance, thus directly affecting PARLAD's activities towards expected results. In general, polarization and radicalization of positions and attitudes have marked the political panorama during the past year. PARLAD members have, however, achieved results with their interventions. Financing civil society dialogue and discussions on current issues and legislative proposals have helped put law initiatives and reforms in Congressional Committee's discussions of issues related to human rights, security, justice and transparency. 10 Commissions have been strengthened through direct technical support and integration of methodologies on dialogue, use of comparative and constitutional law and preparation of technical studies. Among legislative initiatives directly supported by PARLAD are Law on the rights of the disabled (prepared by LEGIS through participatory consultations with representatives of the organized disabled community); Law initiative on Integrated Protection System for Children and Adolescents (also supported by another Embassy partner UNICEF); abolition of the death penalty (with support from another Embassy partner UNHCHR); reforms to the Electoral Law; adaptation of new Migration Code; and installation of an Observatory for Legislative Agenda. Most importantly, the organized civil society has had direct input and participation in the discussions and formulation of legal initiatives in line with the concept of Open Parliament. The Board of Directors received support to modernize the Congressional web site (supported by NDI) which has improved transparency and possibilities for social auditing. Since the beginning of 2018, due to increasing polarization between the Executive Branch, Congress and the public in general, efforts have been re-directed to detaining the regresive legislative agenda, which seeks to limit civil society participation and social audit, restrict human rights and guarantee impunity for politicians suspected of corruption.
